title: Three men jailed over footy fans bashing near MCG after 2018 final
text:
One of the sons of a prominent Melbourne QC will walk from court after mounting an appeal against being jailed for a Melbourne attack on football fans, while his brother remains locked up.

Sam Walker, 25, immediately lodged an appeal on Tuesday after being sentenced at Melbourne Magistrates Court to six months in jail.

He has been released on bail until his appeal on February 3. His brother Dominic Walker, 28, was also sentenced by the same court to 12 months behind bars and their friend, Benjamin Fitt, 28, has been ordered to spend four months in jail.

The trio had each pleaded guilty to two counts of intentionally causing injury to David Raeside and Leonard Tricarico outside the Pullman hotel, a short walk from the MCG, on September 7 last year after an AFL game.

But immediately after their sentence on Tuesday, counsel for Sam Walker and Fitt lodged appeals.

Fitt’s lawyer later told the magistrates court that he would no longer make the application.

It is understood that Dominic Walker has not lodged an appeal but has not ruled out doing so in coming days.

The Walker brothers are the sons of Tim Walker QC and the grandsons of pre-eminent scientist and 2000 Australian of the Year recipient Sir Gustav Nossal.

Magistrate Duncan Reynolds has ordered the trio serve two-year community corrections orders, which includes a year barred from licensed premises, once they’ve completed their prison terms.

Mr Reynolds said the guilty pleas were a concession to their “unjustifiable” conduct during the sustained attack and the group was remorseful. All five men involved were intoxicated to varying degrees, the court was told.

Sam Walker had a history of drug and alcohol use, has bipolar disorder and spent time in a detox program.

Fitt previously had alcohol-related issues, including a previous drink-driving matter in 2011 but has changed his ways, the court was told.
description: One of the sons of a prominent Melbourne QC will walk from court after mounting an appeal against being jailed for a Melbourne attack on football fans, while his brother remains locked up.
